name: Zurich
text: I've been living in Zurich for more than two years. Even though, civilization-wise, Tel-Aviv and Zurich are two western cities (well, kind of...), moving here wasn't a walk in the park. I had to get used to the cold weather, make a mental transformation from being an engineer back to being a green student. I also had to undertake the challenge of a long-distance relationship, which goes without saying. However, slowly but surely, Zurich exposed me what I call: living a normal life, which is something that Israel rather lacks in some ways. From the perspective of a Tel-Avivian, Zurich might seem as a boring city. In my opinion though, it has everything that a human-beings need (with the exception of a good beach): good people, not-too-big, not-too-small, close to year-long beuatiful nature and to every other city in Europe you fancy visiting.

name: Tel-Aviv
text: After finishing my Bachelor's at the Technion I started working for Robotemi, which was located in south Tel-Aviv. Tel-Aviv 'opened my chakras' in several ways, you might even say it is the first real city I've lived in. I got to experience everything good they say about this city: great food, diverse, colorful and crazy people and of course one of the best beach shorelines in the world! I'm sure I'll come back one day, maybe once I have more money in my pocket.

name: Haifa
text: My hometown and where I grew up and where I did my Bachelor's (@ Technion). Haifa is THE prettiest city in Israel. In my view it is the home for the best food in and the best sub-culture in Israel. The one and only holy city. The only downside is that you have to be a local or to know a local to get all of the good stuff. I was also lucky to find a bug in the matrix and to live very close to the beach, in Bat Galim.
